- Link: [Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08325-9?error=cookies_not_supported&code=99fed048-9696-4c0c-81ab-d1c517d6a190)

- Authors: Magee, Jeffrey C.  
- Journal / Date: Nature Neuroscience (2025-06-04)

- Link: [Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3)

web_search.ai_response:
## Overview

**NEURON** is a flexible, widely used simulation environment for modeling individual neurons and networks. It emphasizes biologically realistic models (branched morphologies, membrane biophysics, synapses), supports Python and HOC interfaces, and runs on desktops, cloud, and HPC.

---

## Key resources (from web search)

### Official documentation / guide
- **The NEURON Simulator — NEURON documentation**  
  [NEURON docs (ReadTheDocs)](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/) — installation instructions, programmer’s reference, tutorials, recorded classes, and guides (e.g., “What is NEURON”).  
  - Installation examples: `pip3 install neuron` for macOS/Linux; Windows installer and WSL options documented.
  - Guidance for NEURON >= 9.0 and porting MOD files to C++ is available.

### What NEURON is / features
- **What is NEURON (guide)**  
  [What is NEURON](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/what_is_neuron.html) — concise description of NEURON’s goals and advantages: tailored algorithms for neuronal equations, user-extendable biophysical mechanism library, GUI + scripting (Python/HOC), and emphasis on separating biological concepts from numerical details.

### Source code / repository
- **GitHub: neuronsimulator/nrn**  
  [neuronsimulator/nrn (GitHub)](https://github.com/neuronsimulator/nrn) — source repository, many commits, packaging, docs, CI.  
  ![GitHub NEURON repo image](https://opengraph.githubassets.com/b1d8181cc05872980c05514a630156b181cfeb1d3ea2da1d3aa73c1b6b828929/neuronsimulator/nrn)

### Background / encyclopedia entry
- **Wikipedia — Neuron (software)**  
  [Neuron (software) — Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neuron_(software)) — historical notes (developers Michael Hines, John W. Moore, Ted Carnevale), platform/language/licensing summary, links to the project website.

### Additional educational / simulation resources
- **PhET Neuron interactive (educational)**  
  [PhET: Neuron simulation](https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulations/neuron) — interactive educational simulator for basic neuron concepts.  
  ![PhET Neuron image](https://phet.colorado.edu/sims/html/neuron/latest/neuron-600.png)

---

## Practical notes (from search results)
- Installation: pip install neuron is the recommended quick install for many platforms; platform-specific installers and troubleshooting are documented in the ReadTheDocs site.
- Interfaces: Python, HOC, and a graphical interface — many users script experiments in Python.
- Community & examples: NEURON models on ModelDB and an active forum (neuron.yale.edu phpBB) are referenced from the docs.
- Source & contributions: development happens on GitHub; the repo contains docs, build files, and packaging.

- What is NEURON guide: [What is NEURON](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/what_is_neuron.html)  
- GitHub repo: [neuronsimulator/nrn](https://github.com/neuronsimulator/nrn)

- PhET interactive: [PhET Neuron](https://phet.colorado.edu/en/simulations/neuron)

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
    if total_items is not None and len(all_morphs) >= total_items:
        break

    page += 1

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(all_morphs)}\")
```

Notes:
- The entitysdk has multiple helpers; if it exposes a `.all()` or `.iterate()` convenience that automatically pages, prefer that. Example from docs: `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()`.
- Always check the client response structure for fields like `items`, `total_items`, `limit`, `offset`, or built-in iterators.

---

## 3) Using the entitysdk convenience method shown in examples (single call)

The entitysdk examples show a convenient pattern using search_entity(...).all() to fetch results. If the SDK supports retrieving all with `.all()`, use that:

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# If the client supports .all() to fetch everything (with internal paging)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

print(f\Total morphologies returned: {len(morphs)}\")
for m in morphs[:10]:  # show first 10
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 4) Filtering examples (by mtype or species)

You can pass query filters to narrow results (examples from docs):

- Find morphologies for a specific MType label:

```python
morphs_sr_pc = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\mtype__pref_label\": \SR_PC\"}
).all()
```

- Limit by species (scientific name):

```python
morphs_mouse = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\subject__species__name\": \Mus musculus\"}
).all()
```

---

## Important Platform / EntityCore rules (summary)

- When calling GET ALL endpoints, mention and check `total_items`. Ask before using extra pages if you need to avoid large downloads.
- The EntityCore examples show `client.search_entity(...).all()` as a convenient approach; it may already page for you.
- The SDK examples in the repo demonstrate additional workflows: uploading assets, registering morphologies, adding MType classifications \u2014 see the entitysdk examples for full patterns.

---

If you\u2019d like:
- I can produce a ready-to-run script tailored to your auth method (API key / OAuth) \u2014 tell me which auth you use.
- Or I can show an example using explicit entitycore API parameters (page, page_size) adapted to the exact client methods you have \u2014 tell me which entitysdk version or client functions you see.
software_docs_entitysdk.ai_response:
## Listing all cell morphologies with the EntitySDK (Python)

Below is a compact, copy-pasteable example that shows how to initialize the EntitySDK client and list all **CellMorphology** entities. It uses the same patterns shown in the EntitySDK examples.

### Requirements
- pip install entitysdk
- (optional) pip install obi-auth to fetch tokens for staging
- Set environment variable `ACCESS_TOKEN` with a valid token (or use your token manager)

---

### Example script

```python
# Example: list all CellMorphology entities using entitysdk
import os
from rich import print as rprint

from entitysdk.client import Client
from entitysdk.common import ProjectContext
from entitysdk.models import CellMorphology

# --- Configure client ---
# Replace with your EntityCore URL (or use environment / staging methods)
entitycore_api_url = \http://127.0.0.1:8000\        # change to real API url
project_context = ProjectContext(
    virtual_lab_id=\a98b7abc-fc46-4700-9e3d-37137812c730",
    project_id=\0dbced5f-cc3d-488a-8c7f-cfb8ea039dc6",
)
token = os.getenv(\ACCESS_TOKEN", \XXX")           # set ACCESS_TOKEN in env
client = Client(api_url=entitycore_api_url, project_context=project_context, token_manager=token)

# --- Search for all morphologies ---
# The search_entity(...).all() call returns a list of model instances (paginated internally)
morphologies = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

# --- Inspect results ---
rprint(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(morphologies)}")
# Print a concise summary for the first few
for m in morphologies[:10]:
    # m is a CellMorphology model instance; adapt fields to your use
    rprint({
        \id": m.id,
        
ame": getattr(m, 
ame", None),
         rain_region": getattr(m,  rain_region", None),
        \subject_species": getattr(m, \subject", None) and getattr(m.subject, \species", None),
    })
```

---

### Useful variations and tips
- To search with filters (e.g., species or brain region) use additional parameters on `search_entity` or use the EntitySDK models/filters (see SDK examples).
- The `.all()` method handles pagination internally; if you prefer streaming, check for an iterator API (e.g., `.iter()` or paginated fetch) in your SDK version.
- For staging authentication, consider `obi-auth` helpers (see EntitySDK README / examples).
- If you need full details for a single morphology, use the specific GET-by-id endpoint in the SDK (e.g., `client.get_entity(...)` / dedicated method) — check the EntitySDK docs/examples for the exact call.

If you want, I can:
- Provide an example that filters morphologies by species (e.g., *Mus musculus*) or brain region,
- Show how to fetch assets (SWC files) for each morphology, or
- Convert the output to a pandas DataFrame. Which would you like?

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
## Recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum — selected high-impact papers

Below are recent, relevant studies (2024–2025) that address neuron morphology, whole‑brain morphometry, and cortical dendritic/axonal organization in mammalian cerebrum (mouse/rat) and related model systems. I include title, authors, date, a short summary, a link to the article, and the article image when available.

### 1) Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry  
- **Authors:** Peng, Hanchuan et al.  
- **Published:** 2024-11-26  
- **Summary:** Large-scale whole‑brain morphometry across hundreds of mouse brains. Annotated ~182,497 cell bodies, 15,441 dendritic microenvironments, 1,876 full neuron morphologies, and 2.63M axonal varicosities; registered to the Allen CCF. Emphasizes diversity and stereotypy across multiple morphological scales.  
- **Link:** [Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6)  
![Figure from Peng et al. 2024](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 2) A Multi-Scale Neuron Morphometry Dataset from Peta-voxel Mouse Whole‑Brain Images  
- **Authors:** Peng, Hanchuan et al.  
- **Published:** 2025-04-23  
- **Summary:** Data resource paper describing a cloud-based pipeline and the largest multi‑scale morphometry dataset from peta‑voxel whole‑brain images: tens of thousands of traced morphologies and registration to Allen CCF. Valuable resource for cerebrum morphology analyses and cross-scale studies.  
- **Link:** [A Multi-Scale Neuron Morphometry Dataset from Peta-voxel Mouse Whole-Brain Images](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-025-04379-0)  
![Figure from Peng et al. 2025](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41597-025-04379-0/MediaObjects/41597_2025_4379_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3) An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex  
- **Authors:** Ecker, Alexander S. et al.  
- **Published:** 2025-04-09  
- **Summary:** Data‑driven, graph‑based machine learning mapping of >30,000 excitatory neuron dendritic reconstructions from MICrONS EM volumes (V1, AL, RL). Argues morphological variation is better represented as a continuum with layer‑ and area‑specific trends rather than strictly discrete m‑types.  
- **Link:** [An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w)  
![Figure from Ecker et al. 2025](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 4) Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy (preprint / eLife assessed)  
- **Authors:** Markram H., Schürmann F., Hernando A., et al.  
- **Published:** 2024-08-13 (reviewed preprint)  
- **Summary:** Detailed, large‑scale anatomical model of juvenile rat somatosensory cortex with 4.2M morphologically and biophysically detailed neuron models and 14.2B synapses. Focuses on anatomical construction relevant for micro‑ and mesocircuit morphology and placement. Useful for cerebrum microcircuit anatomy and modeling.  
- **Link:** [Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry — Part I (eLife preprint)](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/99688v1/pdf)

---

### 5) Cell class‑specific long‑range axonal projections of neurons in mouse whisker‑related somatosensory cortices (eLife preprint)  
- **Authors:** Aronoff R., Petersen C.C.H., et al.  
- **Published:** 2024-05-17  
- **Summary:** Brain‑wide light‑sheet imaging and convolutional‑network segmentation of axonal projections from genetically defined cortical neuron classes. Provides layer/subtype‑specific long‑range projection patterns — directly relevant to morphology of projection neurons in the cerebrum.  
- **Link:** [Cell class‑specific long‑range axonal projections … (eLife preprint)](https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/97602v1/pdf)

---

### 6) Neuronal wiring diagram of an adult brain (Drosophila connectome; context for morphology→circuit)  
- **Authors:** Murthy, Mala et al.  
- **Published:** 2024-10-02  
- **Summary:** Whole‑brain connectome for adult Drosophila with ~139k neurons and 5×10^7 chemical synapses. Though not mammalian, this is an example of how full neuron reconstructions + synapse annotations enable wiring diagrams and functional inference — useful conceptual background for large‑scale morphology+connectomics efforts in cerebrum research.  
- **Link:** [Neuronal wiring diagram of an adult brain](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07558-y)  
![Figure from Murthy et al. 2024](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-07558-y/MediaObjects/41586_2024_7558_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

## Want the full texts or deeper extraction?
I can attempt to retrieve and read the full PDFs (when publicly available). If you want, tell me which paper(s) from the list you want the full text or a detailed extraction (methods, datasets, morphological metrics, code/data links), and I will fetch them using the read‑paper tool.

What a "cell morphology" entry typically contains
Each cell morphology record on this page usually includes:

ID and Name of the morphology entry
Species / subject information (e.g., Mus musculus)
Brain region (the region the neuron was recorded/reconstructed from)
M-type(s) or morphological classification
Quantitative measurements (e.g., dendritic length, soma size) and associated units/statistics

Downloadable assets (morphology files) and viewable visualizations
Why the brain region ID matters
The platform uses atlas-driven searches. The page is constrained to show only morphologies that live within (or were assigned to) the brain region represented by the UUID 2a156e47-0842-4a40-bd1e-2afffb4dbafd. The numeric annotation value shown (477) is the atlas annotation corresponding to that region.

simulation_tutorial.user: How can I simulate on the platform ?
simulation_tutorial.expected_output:
Here is a tutorial on how to simulate on the platform, specifically for simulating a single neuron model:

How to Simulate a Single Neuron Model on the Platform
Access Virtual Lab:

From the homepage, click the "Go to Virtual Lab" button.
Manage Projects:

Click on "Projects" in the left menu to see your projects.
Create a project if none exists.
Ensure you have credits in your project; transfer credits from your virtual lab if needed.
Build a Single Neuron Model:

Click on the "Build" column in the left panel.
Click the "Build" button in the single neuron tile.
Name your model, optionally add a description.
Select the brain region (e.g., primary somatosensory area).
Click "Start building."
Select a 3D reconstructed morphology (M model) and an existing electrical model (E model).
Filter morphologies by type (e.g., L5 TPC-A for thick tufted layer 5 pyramidal neuron).
Select the appropriate E model matching the morphology.
Save the created morph-electric model (M E model).
Simulate the Neuron Model:

Go back to your project homepage.
Click on the "Simulate" tab, then "Single Neuron."
Find your neuron model or search by name.
Click your model and press "New Simulation."
In the simulation window, pan, rotate, and zoom the neuron morphology.
Set experiment and simulation parameters.
Choose predefined current injection protocols or customize current steps.
Add multiple recording locations by clicking on the morphology or using the "Add Recording" button.
Press "Simulate" to run the simulation.
View and Save Results:

The "Results" tab will display recordings from selected locations.
Save recordings or save them to the library for later access.
You can watch the full tutorial video here:
How to simulate a single neuron model (Video)

If you want, I can guide you through any specific step or help you start a simulation on the platform.
simulation_tutorial.ai_response:
## Overview

You can run simulations on the Open Brain Platform at multiple scales (single neuron, microcircuit, region, system). Simulations combine digital models (ME-models, point neurons, synaptome/circuit definitions) with experiment configurations (stimulation protocols, recording targets, run settings). Below I summarize what you need, the typical workflow, the platform services/tools you will use, and practical tips.

---

## What you need before simulating

- **A target entity to simulate** — e.g. a **circuit** (microcircuit/region), an **ME-model** (morphology + electrical model), or a **single-neuron simulation** template.  
  - For circuit-level simulations you will need the circuit **ID** (UUID).
  - For single neuron / ME-model runs you will need the ME-model **ID** or exemplar morphology + e-model pair.

- **A complete simulation configuration** describing:
  - Simulation time, time step, and solver settings
  - Stimuli (current injections, synaptic drive, sensory-like inputs)
  - Network composition (which node sets / populations to include, scaling)
  - Synaptic models and plasticity rules (if used)
  - Recording probes (which variables, which cells/populations, sampling rates)
  - Output formats and destinations (files, metrics to compute)

- **Compute resources / run parameters** (if applicable): parallelization, run duration, storage location.

---

## Typical workflow (recommended sequence)

### 1) Choose the model / circuit
- Find the circuit or ME-model you want to run (EntityCore queries). Note the entity **ID** and link.

### 2) Inspect circuit metrics (if running a circuit)
- Retrieve circuit structure and node/edge populations with the obi-one circuit metrics endpoints (this tells you available node sets, edge populations, synapse counts).

### 3) Build a complete simulation configuration (required)
- The platform provides an LLM-backed generator to produce the JSON simulation configuration from a natural-language description.
- Important: always supply a **circuit ID** when requesting a simulation config for a circuit.
- Use the obione-generatesimulationsconfig tool to convert your description into a valid JSON config — do **not** hand-write the final JSON unless you are very experienced with the schema.

What to include in the config:
- Target entity (circuit or ME-model ID)
- Simulation runtime and dt
- Node populations to include / scale factors
- External input specification (rates, amplitudes, patterns)
- Recording list (e.g., membrane potential for N exemplar cells; population spike times)
- Random seeds / reproducibility settings
- Output / logging options

### 4) Validate the config
- Confirm the generated config matches available node/edge names from the metric endpoints.
- Ensure recording targets exist in the selected model.

### 5) Submit and run
- Submit the validated config to the simulation runner (platform service). Monitor status (started / running / success / failure).
- Retrieve outputs (raw traces, spike rasters, aggregate metrics).

### 6) Post-processing and analysis
- Use platform notebooks and analysis tools (Jupyter notebooks provided) to analyze results and create figures.

---

## Platform tools and endpoints (what to use)

- **EntityCore searches**
  - Use entitycore endpoints to find circuits, ME-models, and simulations and to obtain their IDs and links.

- **obi-one metrics**
  - Use obione-circuitmetrics-getone and obione-circuitconnectivitymetrics-getone to inspect circuit structure, node sets, edge populations, and connectivity statistics before configuring a run.

- **Simulation config generator (required for config creation)**
  - Use obione-generatesimulationsconfig to convert your natural-language description of the desired simulation into the JSON configuration the runner expects. Always call this tool to generate or modify simulation configs.

- **Simulation submission / runner**
  - After config generation and validation, submit the config to the simulation service (platform action). The service will return a simulation job ID and status updates.

- **Notebooks / analysis**
  - Platform provides interactive notebooks to analyze outputs and visualize results.

---

## Example request you can give me (I will generate the config for you)

Provide a short natural-language description like:

- “Simulate circuit UUID: <circuit_id> for 5 s with dt=0.025 ms. Include node sets: L2/3_exc (1000 cells), L2/3_inh (250 cells). Drive L2/3_exc with Poisson synaptic input at 5 Hz per neuron. Record 20 random excitatory cells’ somatic Vm at 10 kHz and population spike trains. Save outputs as HDF5.”

What I will do:
- Use that description to call obione-generatesimulationsconfig and return the generated JSON config (and next steps to submit/run).

---

## Validation & reproducibility tips

- Fix random seeds in the config for reproducibility.
- Start with short test runs (e.g., 0.2–1 s) to validate the config and recordings before long production runs.
- Use unit/representative cells as “exemplars” for debugging recordings.

---

## Important notes about UI and navigation
I don't have access to the platform UI and can’t tell you where buttons or menus are. If you need UI-specific guidance (where to click), please consult the platform documentation or contact support. I can, however, help generate/validate simulation configs, query entities, and explain how to interpret outputs.

---

## Next steps — how would you like to proceed?
- Tell me the **target** (circuit ID or ME-model ID) and a natural-language description of the experiment you want and I will generate the simulation configuration JSON using the platform generator.
- Or, if you want, I can first help you find candidate circuits / ME-models (ask me to search by region, species, or name).

software_docs_obione.user: Please show me a code example of how to create a single cell simulation using the obione package.
software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Notes, tips and placeholders
- **Replace** <MEMODEL-ID> with the actual MEModel UUID from EntityCore.
- You need a configured db_client variable (OBI-One examples use a DB client for GridScan generation) \u2014 ensure you have credentials and environment set up as per your installation.
- If you prefer to pick an MEModel interactively or via EntityCore queries, use the platform's EntityCore helpers to get MEModel IDs (examples in the repository show interactive selection).
- The examples above are adapted from the OBI-One example notebooks:
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_with_synapses_simulation.ipynb

If you want, I can:
- provide a minimal runnable script adjusted to your environment (if you give me the MEModel ID and where your db_client/config is stored),
- or show how to query EntityCore for available MEModels and pick one programmatically. Which would you like?
software_docs_obione.ai_response:
## Single-cell simulation — code example (obi-one)

Below is a minimal, self-contained Python example showing how to configure a *single neuron* simulation with the `obi_one` (obi-one) package. It covers: simulation metadata, selecting a single cell, injecting a short current step (somatic current clamp), recording somatic voltage, initializing the simulation, and validating the configuration.

> Replace the placeholders (notably **circuit**) with the circuit object / circuit identifier you want to simulate in your environment.

```python
# Example: single-cell simulation using obi_one
import obi_one as obi

# 1) Simulation metadata
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\Single cell IClamp test",
    campaign_description=\Inject a single step into one neuron and record somatic voltage"
)

# 2) Create an empty CircuitSimulationScanConfig
sim_conf = obi.CircuitSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info")

# 3) Select a single neuron
# Option A: explicitly provide a single ID neuron set (IDs depend on your circuit)
single_neuron_ids = obi.NamedTuple(name=\IDSingle", elements=[0])  # adjust ID to a valid neuron id
single_neuron_set = obi.IDNeuronSet(neuron_ids=single_neuron_ids)
sim_conf.add(single_neuron_set, name=\SingleNeuron")

# Option B (alternative): If you prefer to sample one neuron randomly from a node set:
# single_neuron_set = obi.PredefinedNeuronSet(node_set=\Layer5_PC", sample_percentage=0.01, sample_seed=42)
# sim_conf.add(single_neuron_set, name=\SingleNeuron")

# 4) Define timestamps (one stimulus at t=500 ms)
timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=500.0, interval=1000.0, number_of_repetitions=1)
sim_conf.add(timestamps, name=\StimTimestamps")

# 5) Define a constant current clamp somatic stimulus
# Single-step: duration 200 ms, amplitude 0.3 nA
i_stim = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=timestamps.ref,
    neuron_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    duration=200.0,      # ms
    amplitude=0.3,       # nA
    timestamp_offset=0.0
)
sim_conf.add(i_stim, name=\IClampStimulus")

# 6) Record soma voltage from the selected neuron for the whole simulation
sim_duration = 1200.0  # ms (cover pre, during and post stimulus)
v_rec = obi.SomaVoltageRecording(
    neuron_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    start_time=0.0,
    end_time=sim_duration,
    dt=0.1  # sampling step in ms (10 kHz)
)
sim_conf.add(v_rec, name=\SomaVoltage")

# 7) Initialize simulation (provide your circuit object here)
# NOTE: Replace `circuit` with the actual circuit reference or list of circuits you intend to simulate.
initialize = obi.CircuitSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=circuit,                       # <-- replace with your circuit object
    node_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    simulation_length=sim_duration,
    v_init=-65.0,                          # mV
    extracellular_calcium_concentration=1.25,
```
